message.content: {"name":"Leavey School of Business","description":"The Leavey School of Business confers the Bachelor of Science in Commerce with majors in accounting, accounting and information systems, economics, finance, individual studies, management, marketing, and management information systems. The school also offers departmental minors in business analytics, management information systems, marketing, and real estate, and interdisciplinary minors in entrepreneurship, international business, retail studies, and sustainable food systems.","courseRequirementsExpression":"(BUSN70 & OMIS15) & BUSN85 & (ECON1 & ECON2 & ECON3) & MGMT71 & (ACTG11 & ACTG12) & 2(OMIS40 | OMIS41 | ECON41 | ECON42) & OMIS34 & (FNCE121 & MGMT160 & MKTG181 & OMIS108) & MGMT162","unitRequirements":[{"requirementDescription":"Total quarter units for Bachelor of Science in Commerce","measuredBy":"units","numRequired":175,"typeRequired":"Any","numRequiredFromSCU":0,"mustBeFromDepartmentCode":""},{"requirementDescription":"Upper-division quarter units for Bachelor of Science in Commerce","measuredBy":"units","numRequired":60,"typeRequired":"Upper Division","numRequiredFromSCU":0,"mustBeFromDepartmentCode":""}],"otherRequirements":[{"requirementName":"Prerequisite Requirements","requirementDescription":"Prerequisite requirements must be successfully completed or in progress prior to enrollment in the course that requires the prerequisite."},{"requirementName":"Degree Requirements","requirementDescription":"Students must satisfy the university Core Curriculum, the Leavey School of Business curriculum, and their departmental major."},{"requirementName":"Minors and Interdisciplinary Minors","requirementDescription":"Minors offered include business analytics, management information systems, marketing, real estate, entrepreneurship, international business, retail studies, and sustainable food systems; specific requirements are detailed in the respective department and interdisciplinary minors sections."},{"requirementName":"Individual Studies Petition Requirements","requirementDescription":"To declare the Individual Studies major, students must submit and obtain approval of a petition demonstrating at least one year of full-time enrollment at SCU, a minimum 3.0 overall GPA, a clear description of the proposed program and learning objectives, evidence that no existing program meets the objectives, a plan of study with at least eight upper-division courses beyond core requirements, and signed approval of a tenured or tenure-track faculty advisor; petition is reviewed and approved by the faculty director of Undergraduate Business Programs."}]}

{"name":"College of Arts and Sciences","description":"The College of Arts and Sciences confers Bachelor of Arts degrees in art history, chemistry, classics, communication, English, French and Francophone studies, history, individual studies, Italian studies, music, philosophy, religious studies, Spanish studies, studio art, theatre arts, and gender and sexuality studies; and Bachelor of Science degrees in social sciences and natural sciences disciplines. It also offers a wide array of minors and interdisciplinary minors across diverse fields.","courseRequirementsExpression":"","unitRequirements":[{"requirementDescription":"Minimum quarter units of credit for the degree","measuredBy":"units","numRequired":175,"typeRequired":"Any","numRequiredFromSCU":0,"mustBeFromDepartmentCode":""},{"requirementDescription":"Minimum upper-division quarter units of credit for the degree","measuredBy":"units","numRequired":60,"typeRequired":"Upper Division","numRequiredFromSCU":0,"mustBeFromDepartmentCode":""}],"otherRequirements":[{"requirementName":"Core Curriculum and Major","requirementDescription":"Satisfy the requirements of the undergraduate Core Curriculum and the major"}]}

{"name":"School of Engineering","description":"The School of Engineering confers the Bachelor of Science degree with majors in Bioengineering, Civil Engineering, Computer Science and Engineering, Web Design and Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, General Engineering, and Mechanical Engineering. Specialized programs in Civil Engineering, Computer Science and Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Electrical Engineering, and Mechanical Engineering are ABET-accredited; Bioengineering, General Engineering, and Web Design and Engineering are not yet accredited. The school also offers minors in Aerospace Engineering; Bioengineering; Computer Science and Engineering; Construction Management; Electrical Engineering; Electrical and Computer Engineering; General Engineering; Healthcare Innovation and Design; Mechanical Engineering; and Technical Innovation, Design Thinking, and the Entrepreneurial Mindset. All undergraduate engineering programs require extensive mathematics and natural science sequences, strict enforcement of prerequisites, and completion of the Undergraduate Core Curriculum.","courseRequirementsExpression":"","unitRequirements":[],"otherRequirements":[{"requirementName":"Bachelor of Science Requirements","requirementDescription":"Complete the minimum number of units specified for the major and satisfy the Undergraduate Core Curriculum."},{"requirementName":"Critical Thinking & Writing","requirementDescription":"One two-course sequence in composition: CTW 1 and 2."},{"requirementName":"Advanced Writing","requirementDescription":"ENGL 181."},{"requirementName":"Religion, Theology & Culture","requirementDescription":"Three courses approved to satisfy the core requirements."},{"requirementName":"Cultures & Ideas 1 and 2","requirementDescription":"One course sequence from the approved list of Cultures & Ideas sequences."},{"requirementName":"Cultures & Ideas 3","requirementDescription":"One course from the approved list."},{"requirementName":"Mathematics and Natural Science","requirementDescription":"Course requirements are specified in the respective major requirements."},{"requirementName":"Second Language","requirementDescription":"Recommended proficiency in one foreign language; satisfied by two years of high school study."},{"requirementName":"Social Science","requirementDescription":"One course from the approved list."},{"requirementName":"Civic Engagement","requirementDescription":"One course from the approved list or a combination of ENGR 1 and a senior design project."},{"requirementName":"Ethics","requirementDescription":"One course in general or applied ethics from the approved list."},{"requirementName":"Diversity","requirementDescription":"One course from the approved list."},{"requirementName":"Arts","requirementDescription":"One course from the approved list or a combination of ENGL 181 and a senior design project."},{"requirementName":"Science, Technology & Society","requirementDescription":"One course from the approved list (which includes ENGR 1) or a combination of ENGL 181 and a senior design project."},{"requirementName":"Experiential Learning for Social Justice","requirementDescription":"One course (or activity) approved to satisfy experiential learning."},{"requirementName":"Pathways","requirementDescription":"Three courses with a common theme approved for a declared Pathway."}]}

{"name":"Biology","description":"The Department of Biology offers courses exploring a vast array of biological questions, including core courses for non-majors, introductory curriculum for life research.","majors":[{"name":"Biology","departmentCode":"BIOL","description":"The biology major provides a solid foundation in modern biological concepts and practical skills, emphasizing laboratory {"name":"Art and Art History","description":"The Department of Art and Art History offers Bachelor of Arts degree programs in two majors—Art History and Studio Art—providing students with a thorough understanding of the history and practice of art. {"name":"Medical and Health Humanities","description":"Students in the Medical and Health Humanities minor apply the breadth of the Humanities to key questions and problems that define medicine and health. By exploring the history of medicine, narratives about sickness and health, religious and philosophical beliefs about disease and wellness, and the ethics of health care, students develop a deeper understanding of both the practices of medicine and health sciences as well as the experiences of illness and disability across cultures. Courses emphasize humanistic skills that graduate health and medical programs prize. This minor is open to students majoring in any discipline.","majors":[],"minors":[{"name":"Medical and Health Humanities","departmentCode":"","description":"Students in the Medical and Health Humanities minor apply the breadth of the Humanities to key questions and problems that define medicine and health. By exploring the history of medicine, narratives about sickness and health, religious and philosophical beliefs about disease and wellness, and the ethics of health care, students develop a deeper understanding of both the practices of medicine and health sciences as well as the experiences of illness and disability across cultures. Courses emphasize humanistic skills that graduate health and medical programs prize. This minor is open to students majoring in any discipline.","requiresEmphasis":false,"courseRequirementsExpression":"7@{max_courses_from_one_dept:3}(ANTH134 | ANTH135 | PHSC135 | CLAS41 | CLAS173 | COMM114 | WGST105A | COMM115G | WGST140 | HIST11H | HIST12H | HIST24 | HIST124 | WGST140A | HIST123 | HIST129 | HIST133 | WGST137 | SPAN21S | SPAN101S | PHIL27A | PHIL32 | PHIL113 | PHIL117 | RSOC114 | TESP141)","unitRequirements":[],"otherRequirements":[{"requirementName":"Lower-division courses","requirementDescription":"No more than three courses can be lower-division."},{"requirementName":"Program director approval","requirementDescription":"Courses not included in the approved list may count towards the minor with approval of the program directors."}],"otherNotes":[]}],"emphases":[],"errors":[]}

{"name":"Musical Theatre","description":"Offers experience and training in music, theatre, and dance, as well as musical theatre history. Objectives include entry-level proficiency for a performance career, enhancement in teaching or graduate study; audition techniques; performance in acting, singing, and theatrical dance; and knowledge of cultural history and various forms of musical theatre. Repertoire choices may be made with instructors to focus vocal work in a Broadway or opera style.","majors":[],"minors":[{"name":"Musical Theatre","departmentCode":"","description":"The Musical Theatre Minor offers experience and training in music, theatre, and dance, as well as musical theatre history. The objectives of this program include entry-level proficiency for a career in performance, enhancement in teaching, or further training in graduate school; audition techniques; performance of acting, singing, and theatrical dance; and knowledge of the cultural history and various forms of musical theatre. Students may, through repertoire choices decided in consultation with their instructors, focus their vocal work with emphasis on a Broadway or more opera style.","requiresEmphasis":false,"courseRequirementsExpression":"(MUSC34 & 1(THTR8 | THTR10 | THTR24) & 4(DANC40-47 | DANC55 | DANC155) & 2(THTR123 | THTR165 | THTR80 | THTR180 | MUSC53 | MUSC153))","unitRequirements":[{"requirementDescription":"On-campus private voice instruction","measuredBy":"courses","numRequired":3,"typeRequired":"Any","numRequiredFromSCU":3,"mustBeFromDepartmentCode":"MUSC"}],"otherRequirements":[{"requirementName":"Music Theory and Aural Skills","requirementDescription":"One course each in Music Theory and Aural Skills (suggested: MUSC 1 and 1A; placement tests may be taken to determine if a higher level is appropriate)."}],"otherNotes":["Placement test required; if a higher proficiency level is attained, an additional three quarters of on-campus private voice instruction may substitute for the MUSC 34 requirement.","DANC 40 and 41 recommended for those interested in Broadway."]}],"emphases":[],"errors":[]}

{"name":"International Business","description":"The minor in international business is designed to educate students in a broad range of management and business skills in a global context. The program includes coursework in language, social science, and international business, and is open to all undergraduate students. The minor provides students with an understanding of the social, economic, and political context of international business, the language communication skills, and the business skills to be effective managers in a global marketplace. Students are encouraged to participate in a study abroad program or internship to complement this minor.","majors":[],"minors":[{"name":"International Business","departmentCode":"","description":"The minor in international business is designed to educate students in a broad range of management and business skills in a global context. The program includes coursework in language, social science, and international business, and is open to all undergraduate students. The minor provides students with an understanding of the social, economic, and political context of international business, the language communication skills, and the business skills to be effective managers in a global marketplace.","requiresEmphasis":false,"courseRequirementsExpression":"1(ARAB23 | CHIN23 | FREN100 | GERM100 | ITAL100 | JAPN23 | SPAN23) & (BUSN70 | BUSN170) & (ACTG11 | ACTG11A) & ECON1 & ECON2 & ECON3 & MGMT80 & 1(MGMT6 | PHIL26) & 2(ENVS50 | ECON129 | ECON134 | ECON138 | HIST105 | POLI50 | POLI119 | POLI121 | POLI122 | POLI136 | POLI137 | POLI140 | POLI142 | POLI144 | POLI146 | PSYC162 | SOCI138) & 2(FNCE151 | MGMT110 | MGMT170 | MKTG178 | ECON181 | ECON182)","unitRequirements":[],"otherRequirements":[{"requirementName":"Language proficiency demonstration","requirementDescription":"Students who feel they already have the required level of language competency must demonstrate such by completing one of the approved courses or a more advanced 100- or 101-level course. Other languages do not qualify."},{"requirementName":"Additional social science approval","requirementDescription":"Other eligible selected comparative politics courses may be approved by the director of the international business minor program."}],"otherNotes":["Completion of advanced language courses","Participation in study abroad programs; approved equivalent courses taken abroad may fulfill requirements of the minor","Internship related to an international business career","Additional coursework in economic development, modern history, and politics of selected world regions"]}],"emphases":[],"errors":[]}

{"name":"Child Studies","description":"The Child Studies program prepares students for careers working with children and families in school or community settings. The curriculum emphasizes social justice, anti-racist practice, and cultural competence. Students work extensively with children and families in local schools and community-based programs, and the faculty addresses issues affecting marginalized populations—including education policy, the preschool-to-prison pipeline, socio-emotional processes, political dynamics, community organizing, and institutional change. Graduates earn a Bachelor of Science and are prepared for graduate studies and professional vocations in fields such as teacher education, social work, counseling, psychology, law, speech and language pathology, occupational therapy, and nonprofit agencies.","majors":[{"name":"Child Studies","departmentCode":"CHST","description":"Designed for undergraduates interested in careers working with children and families in school or community settings, with a curriculum emphasizing social justice, anti-racist perspective, and cultural competence. Students engage extensively with local schools and community-based programs to address issues affecting marginalized populations. Graduates earn a Bachelor of Science and are prepared for advanced study and professional careers in education, social services, counseling, law, therapy, and nonprofit work.","requiresEmphasis":false,"courseRequirementsExpression":"(CHST3 & CHST4 & CHST5 & CHST6 & CHST11 & CHST12 & CHST75 & CHST100 & CHST101 & CHST102 & CHST104 & CHST106 & CHST180 & CHST181 & CHST182) & (PSYC2 & PSYC185) & 1(CHST66 | CHST109 | CHST114 | CHST115 | CHST154Y | CHST138 | CHST190 | CHST199 | ENVS131 | PSYC134 | PSYC172)","unitRequirements":[],"otherRequirements":[],"otherNotes":["Students must also fulfill undergraduate Core Curriculum requirements for the Bachelor of Science degree."]}],"minors":[],"emphases":[],"errors":[]}

{"name":"Individual Studies","description":"The Individual Studies Program (ISP) allows students to design a custom, multidisciplinary course of study leading to a B.A. or a B.S. in social science. Coursework must be drawn from a significant number of existing offerings across multiple disciplines (independent study and directed readings are discouraged), with no more than four study‐abroad courses counting toward the major. Each ISP student must secure a continuing SCU faculty member as an advisor to review and approve the program of study, provide at least annual advising, and complete the student’s pre‐graduation audit.","majors":[{"name":"Individual Studies","departmentCode":"","description":"Students design an individualized interdisciplinary curriculum approved by a faculty advisor. The plan must demonstrate curricular diversity, rely primarily on existing courses, and may include up to four study‐abroad courses.","requiresEmphasis":false,"courseRequirementsExpression":"","unitRequirements":[],"otherRequirements":[{"requirementName":"Eligibility Requirements","requirementDescription":"Be a full-time student at Santa Clara for at least one year; have fewer than 111 quarter units completed at time of application; maintain a minimum GPA of 3.0."},{"requirementName":"Petition Requirements","requirementDescription":"Submit a Petition for Admission to the ISP director, including: a clear and conceptually refined description of the proposed program; an argument demonstrating that no existing major meets the student’s objectives; a plan of study listing courses, seminars, internships, etc., that fulfills Core Curriculum and educational goals; and identification of a faculty advisor whose expertise aligns with the proposed area of study."}],"otherNotes":["Students should begin by scheduling a meeting with the program director to obtain a list of administrative instructions and guidance."]}],"minors":[],"emphases":[],"errors":[]}

{"name":"Economics","description":"As one of the social sciences, economics studies how the choices we make as individuals—as consumers and producers, as savers and investors, as managers and employees, as citizens and voters—combine to determine how society uses its scarce resources to produce and distribute goods and services. This practical discipline provides insights into important issues such as the determinants of wealth and poverty—unemployment, inflation, international trade, and economic growth; as well as success and failure in the marketplace. The rigorous, systematic analysis that the study of economics brings to bear on these and other real-world issues provides excellent preparation for careers in both the private and the public sectors, as well as for graduate study in economics, business, public policy, and law. Economics graduates pursue varied careers in business, law, banking and finance, government service, education, and private consulting. Students considering graduate study in economics leading to a master’s or doctoral degree are strongly encouraged to meet with their advisor as early as possible to plan an appropriate course of {"name":"Catholic Studies","description":"The minor in Catholic studies, open to students from all departments, is an interdisciplinary program for the study of the intellectual tradition of the Catholic faith. The minor is designed for intensive study of Catholicism as a faith embedded in many cultures and for the critical retrieval of the Catholic intellectual tradition through dialogue with contemporary thought under the rubrics of a variety of academic disciplines. Catholic studies minors are assigned a faculty mentor who guides them through the program. {"name":"Entrepreneurship","description":"The entrepreneurship minor provides students interested in developing a business or working in a startup the chance to explore that career option and acquire skills for success. Students learn the venture creation process—from generating and developing a business concept, applying analytical tools to identify and evaluate opportunities, creating and evaluating a business plan, to analyzing funding sources. A critical element is an internship with an emerging for-profit or social benefit organization. The minor is open to all students via application to the Management and Entrepreneurship Department. Business school students may begin after earning 60 units; non-business students should ideally complete prerequisites by their sophomore year.","majors":[],"minors":[{"name":"Entrepreneurship","departmentCode":"MGMT","description":"Students complete three core courses in entrepreneurship and two electives from a broad list of business, engineering, economics, environmental studies, finance, marketing, public health science, and sociology courses.","requiresEmphasis":false,"courseRequirementsExpression":"(MGMT164 & MGMT165 & MGMT198E & 2(BUSN197 | ECON129 | ECON185 | ENVS145 | ENVS148 | FNCE141 | FNCE143 | FNCE170 | MECH144 | MGMT172 | HRNS120A | MGMT175 | MGMT177 | ENGR161 | MKTG175 | MKTG177 | MKTG182 | MKTG187 | PHSC157 | SOCI150 | SOCI172))","unitRequirements":[],"otherRequirements":[{"requirementName":"Internship concurrency","requirementDescription":"The internship must run concurrent with the course, and students cannot use past experiences toward credit in this course."}],"otherNotes":[]}],"emphases":[],"errors":[]}

{"name":"Retail Studies","description":"The Retail Studies minor, offered by the Retail Management Institute (RMI) in SCU’s Leavey School of Business, provides an in-depth hands-on experience preparing students for diverse roles in retail—including e-commerce, buying, merchandising, planning and allocation, digital marketing, and supply chain management. {"name":"Pre-Law","description":"Santa Clara University’s Pre-Law program provides undergraduates with advising and resources to build a strong foundation for law school. Students work with designated pre-law advisors to assess fit for a legal career, understand the LSAT and application process, and prepare for employment as attorneys. {"name":"Neuroscience","description":"A Bachelor of Science degree in neuroscience at SCU provides the scientific foundation to understand the nervous system at multiple levels—from molecular mechanisms to patient symptomatology—using interdisciplinary approaches that integrate biological, computational, and psychological perspectives. {"name":"Health Professions Advising","description":"The Santa Clara University Health Professions Advising program advises, mentors, supports, and educates pre-health students preparing for careers such as dentistry, medicine (allopathic and osteopathic), physical therapy, optometry, pharmacy, and more. Directed by Dr. Brian J. McNelis, the program uses national acceptance data and best practices to guide individualized advising. Advising is delivered through a Canvas Camino “course” (with about 400 students and 10,000 page-views per month) and Drahmann Center appointments, and is reinforced by 16 peer advisors who offer one-on-one appointments, drop-in advising, workshops, and mentorship groups. First-year students participate in a structured mentorship program, and an Executive Board oversees alumni outreach, community building, and program development. The program’s Camino modules cover introduction to the program, advising resources, curriculum planning, career exploration, experiential opportunities, testing support, application support, conferences, student groups, certifications, and post-graduation resources. Additional resources include quick guides for pre-medical, pre-PA, pre-pharmacy, pre-PT, and pre-optometry paths, and alumni engagement via a LinkedIn group and Bronco Exchange collaboration.","majors":[],"minors":[],"emphases":[],"errors":[]}

{"name":"Sustainable Food Systems","description":"The Sustainable Food Systems minor provides students with the opportunity to explore the intersection of global food systems and sustainability. {"name":"Finance","description":"Finance is at the center of well-managed businesses, from high technology companies to mutual fund companies. Development of knowledge and managerial skills in the corporate and investment settings are the major goals of the finance program. Graduates with a degree in finance pursue careers as corporate financial officers, traders, investment managers, financial analysts, financial planners, investment bankers, stockbrokers, regulators, and other specialties. Corporate finance officers manage the assets and value of corporations. They examine which new products and investments will be profitable, analyze the most cost-effective ways to produce them, and determine where to get the money needed to fund new ventures. Personal financial planners and stockbrokers help people make wise investments by selecting good stocks and assembling efficient portfolios. Students in finance also learn how to understand and analyze information from capital markets, engage in mergers and acquisitions, and undertake investments in new ventures, real estate, and international markets.","majors":[{"name":"Finance","departmentCode":"FNCE","description":"Development of knowledge and managerial skills in corporate and investment settings, preparing graduates for careers as corporate financial officers, traders, investment managers, financial analysts, planners, bankers, stockbrokers, regulators, and other specialties.","requiresEmphasis":false,"courseRequirementsExpression":"(FNCE124 & FNCE125 & (MATH12 | MATH31 | FNCE186) & 4((FNCE100-199) & !(FNCE118 | FNCE127 | FNCE129 | FNCE131)))","unitRequirements":[],"otherRequirements":[{"requirementName":"Core and College Requirements","requirementDescription":"In addition to fulfilling undergraduate Core Curriculum and Leavey School of Business requirements for the bachelor of science in commerce degree."},{"requirementName":"Elective Qualification Note","requirementDescription":"FNCE 186 qualifies as one of the four upper-division finance electives; {"name":"English","description":"The Department of English affords students a rich undergraduate education in the liberal arts centered on literature, cultural studies, and writing. Critical, professional, or creative writing projects are integral to every course in the English major. Students and faculty in the English Department discuss and write about British, American, and global literature, technical and professional communication, new media, and film. A range of theoretical approaches are used, sometimes with a focus on visual rhetoric and cultural studies. The department also offers the Creative Writing Minor, which provides students with a coherent course of study in the writing of poetry, fiction, and creative nonfiction, and the Professional Writing Minor, which focuses on the theories, ethics, and practice of writing in industry and public contexts. {"name":"Religious Studies","description":"The Department of Religious Studies offers a Bachelor of Arts in Religious Studies and a minor in theological and religious studies. {"name":"Communication","description":"The Department of Communication offers a bachelor of arts in communication, preparing students for careers in communication, entertainment, technology, journalism, and nonprofit sectors, as well as graduate studies in communication, film, journalism, and law. Students explore theories, research methods, responsibilities, institutional structures, and effects across mass, interpersonal, strategic, global, and computer-mediated communication, integrating theory and practice to create speeches, films, television programs, journalism, web content, and marketing campaigns. The program encourages a broad liberal arts education, integration with other departments, global studies via approved study abroad courses, and internships as elective credit. Students may pursue a general degree or one of six official emphases. A minor in digital filmmaking or journalism is also available. {"name":"Military Science Program","description":"The Military Science Program offers ROTC courses open to Santa Clara and cross-enrolled university students, developing management and leadership skills for corporate and military careers. Completers are eligible for commissioning as officers in the U.S. Army. The core curriculum consists of six lower-division ROTC Basic Course classes (MILS 11, 12, 13, 21, 22, 23) or a MILS 24 summer camp and seven upper-division ROTC Advanced Course classes (MILS 131, 132, 133, 134, 141, 142, 143). {"name":"Experiential Learning for Social Justice","description":"The Experiential Learning for Social Justice (ELSJ) component of Santa Clara’s Core Curriculum cultivates social justice, civic life, perspective, and civic engagement. {"name":"University Honors Program","description":"The University Honors Program offers small, seminar-style classes that emphasize critical thinking, analytical rigor, effective expression, and interactive learning, culminating in a collaborative senior-year thesis.
